Description: Rim sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; trace of palmette in added white and elaborate lotus flower in white outline with added red centres; top of rim glazed; exterior: frieze of alternating red and black tongues above zigzag band between lines; below trace of group of short vertical strokes as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University College London. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd joins British Museum 1888,0601.465.b and belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.465.a, 1888,0601.465.c, 1888,0601.465.d, 1888,0601.465.e, Paris E8056 bis.22, London, UCL-393 and Boston 88.830. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1965, 0930.338. Lemos identifies this sherd as coming from a phiale. She does discuss other sherds from the same heavy chalice and describes them as coming from a mediocre but big chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are therefore known as heavy chalices; they display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Johnston 1978 / Pottery from Naukratis: An Exhibition on the Occasion of the 11th International Congress of Classical Archaeology (no. 90)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 270, no. 682, pl. 90)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1599) (phase 2)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: UCL n.p. 73 (Other Accession Number)
